articles.headline: Senators Ask Who Got Money From A.I.G.
articles.snippet: A Senate panel told the Federal Reserve to identify all the parties made whole by the bailout of A.I.G. or forget about coming back to ask Congress for more rescue money.
articles.abstract: A Senate panel told the Federal Reserve to identify all the parties made whole by the bailout of A.I.G. or forget about coming back to ask Congress for more rescue money.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Trying to draw a line in the sand, a Senate panel told the vice chairman of the Federal Reserve to identify all the parties made whole by the bailout of the American International Group or forget about coming back to ask Congress for more rescue money.

articles.headline: Food Problems Elude Private Inspectors
articles.snippet: Food manufacturers are increasingly hiring private auditors, but problems with contamination remain.
articles.abstract: Food manufacturers are increasingly hiring private auditors, but problems with contamination remain.
articles.lead_paragraph: When food industry giants like Kellogg want to ensure that American consumers are being protected from contaminated products, they rely on private inspectors like Eugene A. Hatfield. So last spring Mr. Hatfield headed to the Peanut Corporation of America plant in southwest Georgia to make sure its chopped nuts, paste and peanut butter were safe to use in things as diverse as granola bars and ice cream.
articles.byline: By Michael Moss and Andrew Martin

articles.headline: The Deal That Fueled Subprime
articles.snippet: In 2002, HSBC bought into the subprime sector, giving it new credibility. Now the bank exits, tattered.
articles.abstract: In 2002, HSBC bought into the subprime sector, giving it new credibility. Now the bank exits, tattered.
articles.lead_paragraph: There are times when a corporate takeover has importance far beyond the companies involved.

articles.headline: Japan’s Slump Tests Faith in the Resilience of Stocks
articles.snippet: Japan’s experience demonstrates how a modern stock market can atrophy, and may offer lessons for other nations.
articles.abstract: Japan’s experience demonstrates how a modern stock market can atrophy, and may offer lessons for other nations.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO  When Japan’s stock market took a nose dive in 1990, analysts told Shizuko Kitamura to take the long view, just invest consistently and stoically and wait for share prices to recover.

articles.headline: Piecemeal Layoffs Avoid Warning Laws
articles.snippet: Experts say the law requiring notice of certain kinds of layoffs should be overhauled to cover smaller job cuts.
articles.abstract: Experts say the law requiring notice of certain kinds of layoffs should be overhauled to cover smaller job cuts.
articles.lead_paragraph: With the economy weakening, chief executives want Wall Street to see them as tough cost-cutters who are not afraid to lay off workers. But plenty of job cuts are not trumpeted in news releases.

articles.headline: Undisclosed Losses at Merrill Lynch Lead to a Trading Inquiry
articles.snippet: In the final, frantic months of 2008, Merrill traders apparently lost hundreds of millions on gambles that came to light only after its merger with Bank of America.
articles.abstract: In the final, frantic months of 2008, Merrill traders apparently lost hundreds of millions on gambles that came to light only after its merger with Bank of America.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  One Merrill Lynch trader apparently gambled away more than $120 million in the currency markets. Others seemingly lost hundreds of millions on tricky credit derivatives.
articles.byline: By Louise Story and Eric Dash

articles.headline: Slump Humbling Blue-Chip Stocks
articles.snippet: Shares in companies that are household names, like G.E. and G.M., now trade for pocket change.
articles.abstract: Shares in companies that are household names, like G.E. and G.M., now trade for pocket change.
articles.lead_paragraph: The banking giant Citigroup commanded a stock price of $55 just two years ago. But at one point Thursday, as markets hurtled to their lowest close in 12 years, the shares were worth less than an item at the Dollar Store.

articles.headline: Job Losses Hint at Vast Remaking of Economy
articles.snippet: With unemployment at 8.1 percent, some economists believe that a wrenching restructuring is under way.
articles.abstract: With unemployment at 8.1 percent, some economists believe that a wrenching restructuring is under way.
articles.lead_paragraph: As government data revealed that 651,000 more jobs disappeared in February, a sense took hold that growing joblessness may reflect a wrenching restructuring of the American economy.
articles.byline: By Peter S. Goodman and Jack Healy
